Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "Add GitHubVulnerabilities2Db Job" (#7663) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Part of https://github.com/nuget/nugetgallery/issues/7648

This PR adds the GitHubVulnerabilities2Db job itself, which primarily consists of querying GitHub's GraphQL API and then converting the response into our DB entities.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Trying to upload while another upload is incomplete gives a blank page with "The page was not displayed because there was a conflict."" (#267) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
1. Tab A go to https://preview.nuget.org/packages/upload
2. Tab B go to https://preview.nuget.org/packages/upload
3. Tab A, upload a package, don't verify/cancel
4. Tab B, Upload a package 

Blank page with text :

"The page was not displayed because there was a conflict."

Low pri but the blank page is not so nice, could just redirect to the first package to finish.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "Removes the height differences when switching to the organization page" (#7667) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
I was browsing through the NuGet UI and notices a UI glitch on the organization page:

![before](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/756703/67987512-e2c80d00-fc2d-11e9-8a84-ad7dad5efcb4.gif)

The "divider" is using the "ms-font-xxl", which enlarges the complete navigation bread crumb area. With a smaller version it keeps the same size as similar pages. 

![after](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/756703/67987637-36d2f180-fc2e-11e9-8d4c-3d64e158701d.gif)

Be aware:
There are (at least) two other pages with this xxl dividers, but they have some other controls on the same line, so... it would be more complicated to fix those.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/756703/67987679-510ccf80-fc2e-11e9-87a8-45fb66eb57cc.png)

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/756703/67987717-67b32680-fc2e-11e9-9bce-b65277d9cf6e.png)

Hope this helps :)

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Nupkg structure for multi framework (45 - 471) support + net standard ( Github Issue : https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/6739 )" (#8785) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
I have a c# library. It has some different apis in netstandard than net47.

I want to generate a nupkg which should be usable from both .net specific framework and .net coreclr projects. So, if someone creates a fullframework net46/net47 project Or coreclr project targeting netcoreapp2.0 or net47, it should pick up dll based on its version. Also, for .net standard, since it targets multiple platform, I have `Linux` and `win` specific dll.

How should I structure my nupkg so that during compilation and packaging, it takes the right dll ?

I have the following structure of nupkg :

```
my_lib.NUPKG
|   my_lib.nuspec
|   [Content_Types].xml
|
+---lib
|   \---net45
|           my_lib.dll
|           my_lib.xml
|
+---package
|   \---services
|       \---metadata
|           \---core-properties
|                   f173822ccbd74dfb9a5338af5508d1b6.psmdcp
|
+---ref
|   \---netstandard2.0
|           my_lib.dll
|
+---runtimes
|   +---linux
|   |   \---lib
|   |       \---netstandard2.0
|   |               my_lib.dll
|   |
|   \---win
|       \---lib
|           +---net461
|           |       my_lib.dll
|           |
|           +---net462
|           |       my_lib.dll
|           |
|           +---net47
|           |       my_lib.dll
|           |
|           +---net471
|           |       my_lib.dll
|           |
|           \---netstandard2.0
|                   my_lib.dll  // this is different from above my_lib.dll
|
\---_rels
        .rels

```

This is working for most cases.

However, when user creates a .net sdk coreclr project targeting net471 using dotnet cli :
```
<Project Sdk="Microsoft.NET.Sdk">
<PropertyGroup>
  <TargetFramework>net47</TargetFramework>
</PropertyGroup>
```
during compilation, it refers to netstandard2.0 dll and fails to compile. If I comment out the incompatible apis, in the generated build, it has right net47 `my_lib.dll`. This means that during compilation `only`, it is referring to netstandard2.0 dll.  

I think that their might be something wrong with how I have structured my nupkg.
What is the right way for this ? Can you point me to some documentation around this ?

## Details about Problem

NuGet product used (NuGet.exe | VS UI | Package Manager Console | dotnet.exe):

NuGet version (x.x.x.xxx): 
```
NuGet.exe help
NuGet Version: 3.4.3.855
```

dotnet.exe --version (if appropriate):
```
.NET Command Line Tools (2.0.3)

Product Information:
 Version:            2.0.3
 Commit SHA-1 hash:  12f0c7efcc

Runtime Environment:
 OS Name:     Windows
 OS Version:  10.0.16299
 OS Platform: Windows
 RID:         win10-x64
 Base Path:   C:\Program Files\dotnet\sdk\2.0.3\

Microsoft .NET Core Shared Framework Host

  Version  : 2.0.3
  Build    : a9190d4a75f4a982ae4b4fa8d1a24526566c69df
```
VS version (if appropriate): `15.4.5`

OS version : `win 10 enterprise v1709 16299.309`



---

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Test:  improve signing certificate V1/V2 testing" (#8762) at NuGet/Home
Closed issue "Nuget 5.0.2 fails to find msbuild assemblies in debian stretch" (#8137) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Hi,

I'm trying to package a csharp project in Linux using nuget+mono. Specifically the OS is a debian stretch: Linux dc1e45079844 4.9.0-3-amd64 SMP Debian 4.9.30-2+deb9u5 (2017-09-19) x86_64 GNU/Linux

It's been working fine with NuGet 4.6.2, but since updating to 5.0.2 when running `nuget restore project.sln` I get the following error:

MSBuild auto-detection: using msbuild version '' from '/usr/bin'.
Error parsing solution file at /project_folder/project.sln: Could not load file or assembly '/usr/bin/Microsoft.Build.dll' or one of its dependencies
NuGet.CommandLine.CommandLineException: Error parsing solution file at /project_folder/project.sln: Could not load file or assembly '/usr/bin/Microsoft.Build.dll' or one of its dependencies

It seems that with the new version the Msbuild auto-detection is failing to find the correct paths, given that the Microsoft.Build.dll  is located in /usr/lib/mono/xbuild/14.0/bin/ but nuget seems to be looking for it in /usr/bin. 

Thanks

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Investigate DiagnosticsSource for protocol diagnostics" (#8784) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
System.Net.Http.HttpClient emits events though DiagnosticSource: https://github.com/dotnet/corefx/blob/master/src/System.Net.Http/src/HttpDiagnosticsGuide.md

Note, it works on both .NET Framework and .NET Core, but the event names are different (probably because the event datastructure is different), so if we use it, it's important to test both runtimes. Also, check what happens on mono.

This will let us get much more detailed information, if we want it, but depending on what we want, it might also not give us the level of information we want.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "vs/nuget/nugetaction doesn't log the packages added, removed, or updated" (#8783) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem

NuGet product used: VS UI

NuGet version (x.x.x.xxx):

VS version (if appropriate): 16.4.0 preview 3.0
OS version (i.e. win10 v1607 (14393.321)): win10 1909 build 18363.418
Worked before? If so, with which NuGet version: No

## Detailed repro steps so we can see the same problem

1. Launch VS. Open C# console app. Manage nuget packages for project. Use fiddler or another tool to examine VS telemetry leaving the machine.
2. select a nuget package to install
3. click install
4. accept all the installation prompts
5. find the vs/nuget/nugetaction event in the telemetry monitor

Expected: information about which packages were added, updated, or removed from the project
Actual: no package information

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "vs/nuget/nugetaction telemetry doesn't adequately capture cancellation" (#8782) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem

NuGet product used VS UI

NuGet version (x.x.x.xxx): 

VS version (if appropriate): 16.4.0 preview 3.0 

OS version (i.e. win10 v1607 (14393.321)): win10 1909 build 18363.418

Worked before? If so, with which NuGet version: No

## Detailed repro steps so we can see the same problem

1. Launch VS.  Open C# console app.  Manage nuget packages for project.  Use fiddler or another tool to examine VS telemetry leaving the machine.

2. select a nuget package to install
3. click install
4. at one of the various promps, choose "cancel" instead of continue
5. Look for the vs/nuget/nugetaction event

Expected: install state doesn't indicate "Success"
Actual: event suggests that packages were actually installed

When the user cancels for some reason, the event should indicate that they cancelled, and should give additional reasons on why/where they cancelled.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "How to include additional files in lib" (#8780) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
I have a .Net Core project that contains additional project referenced dlls and these are not added to the nuget package.  
``` xml
  <ItemGroup>
    <ProjectReference Include="..\CodeGen.Generator\CodeGen.Generator.csproj" />
    <ProjectReference Include="..\CodeGen.Interfaces\CodeGen.Interfaces.csproj" />
    <ProjectReference Include="..\CodeGen.Loaders\CodeGen.Loaders.csproj" />
  </ItemGroup>
```
The question then is how can I add these dependent dlls into the the package? 

1. I tried the `ProjectGroup.IncludeBuiltProjectOutputGroup` but mustn't be using the correct value if that is the solution. 
1. I tried adding a nuspec file but that did not help, i assume since VS creates it's own.
1. I notice the ItemGroup has a Content for adding "other" files into the content folder of the package, is there an equivalent Lib?  I couldn't see it, if it does.

When I loaded the nuget package in the Nuget Package Explorer and output the metadata as a nuspec file I received the following:
```xml
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<package xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/packaging/2012/06/nuspec.xsd">
  <metadata>
    <id>OurPresence.CodeGen</id>
    <version>1.0.0</version>
    <authors>Allan Nielsen</authors>
    <owners>Allan Nielsen</owners>
    <requireLicenseAcceptance>false</requireLicenseAcceptance>
    <projectUrl>https://github.com/allann/codegen</projectUrl>
    <description>Code generator using model files and compiled template components</description>
    <copyright>Copyright 2019</copyright>
    <tags>code generator c#</tags>
    <repository type="git" url="https://github.com/allann/codegen" />
    <dependencies>
      <group targetFramework=".NETCoreApp2.1">
        <dependency id="CodeGen.Generator" version="1.0.0" exclude="Build,Analyzers" />
        <dependency id="CodeGen.Interfaces" version="1.0.0" exclude="Build,Analyzers" />
        <dependency id="CodeGen.Loaders" version="1.0.0" exclude="Build,Analyzers" />
        <dependency id="McMaster.Extensions.CommandLineUtils" version="2.4.1" exclude="Build,Analyzers" />
        <dependency id="McMaster.Extensions.Hosting.CommandLine" version="2.4.1" exclude="Build,Analyzers" />
        <dependency id="Microsoft.Extensions.Configuration.EnvironmentVariables" version="2.2.4" exclude="Build,Analyzers" />
        <dependency id="Microsoft.Extensions.Configuration.Json" version="2.2.0" exclude="Build,Analyzers" />
        <dependency id="Microsoft.Extensions.DependencyInjection" version="2.2.0" exclude="Build,Analyzers" />
        <dependency id="Microsoft.Extensions.Hosting" version="2.2.0" exclude="Build,Analyzers" />
        <dependency id="Microsoft.Extensions.Hosting.Abstractions" version="2.2.0" exclude="Build,Analyzers" />
        <dependency id="Microsoft.Extensions.Logging.Console" version="2.2.0" exclude="Build,Analyzers" />
        <dependency id="Microsoft.Extensions.Logging.Debug" version="2.2.0" exclude="Build,Analyzers" />
        <dependency id="Serilog.AspNetCore" version="3.0.0" exclude="Build,Analyzers" />
        <dependency id="Serilog.Sinks.Console" version="3.1.1" exclude="Build,Analyzers" />
        <dependency id="Serilog.Sinks.File" version="4.0.0" exclude="Build,Analyzers" />
      </group>
    </dependencies>
  </metadata>
  <files>
    <file src="lib\netcoreapp2.1\codegen.dll" target="lib\netcoreapp2.1\codegen.dll" />
    <file src="lib\netcoreapp2.1\codegen.runtimeconfig.json" target="lib\netcoreapp2.1\codegen.runtimeconfig.json" />
  </files>
</package>
```
The CodeGen.*.dll files need to be included as files and NOT dependencies because they dont exist as NuGet packages (and shouldn't be).


---
#### Document Details

* Version Independent ID: 3bf15a5c-8b3e-0e69-0bf6-03b44654970c

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Xamarin projects in Visual Studio do not use .targets in NuGet package references" (#8642) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Please read the following information before posting the issue.

## Details about Problem

NuGet product used: VS2019 UI

## Detailed repro steps so we can see the same problem

1. Create a new Xamarin.iOS or Xamarin.tvOS application from the template.

2. Reference a NuGet package that uses a custom .targets file located in `\build`

It appears Xamarin projects in Visual Studio ignore the `.targets` file that ships with a NuGet package reference. Furthermore it is not possible to use `GeneratePathProperty` on the `PackageReference` to workaround this by manually importing the .targets file, since the path is not generated:

```xml
 <ItemGroup>
    <!-- GeneratePathProperty is ignored -->
    <PackageReference Include="fnalibs" GeneratePathProperty="true">
      <Version>19.9.0-pre</Version>
    </PackageReference>
  </ItemGroup>
  <Import Project="$(MSBuildExtensionsPath)\Xamarin\TVOS\Xamarin.TVOS.CSharp.targets" />
  <!-- .targets file is not used by Xamarin projects in VS (and this workaround doesn't work) -->
  <Import Project="$(Pkgfnalibs)build\fnalibs.targets" />
```

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "NuGet Restore Manager spec images" (#8777) at NuGet/Home
Opened issue "Interop Assembly in NuGet for Standard and Framework with EmbedInteropTypes = false" (#8776) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Hi all

I am trying to create a NuGet package with just an interop assembly inside.
This package will be used in .NET Standard, Core and Framework projects.
The package should make sure that `EmbedInteropTypes` is in all cases set to `false`.
I'm having a hard time achieving this. I tried to do it like the sample `https://github.com/NuGet/Samples/tree/master/NuGet.Samples.Interop` and just adjusting the `true` to `false` but I do not see anything added regarding `EmbedInteropTypes` in the csproj file. Neither on .NET Core nor on .NET Framework.

I don't really understand when the target file is needed and when it will work. Will it also work for .NET Framework? Or do I need an `install.ps` there which disables the `EmbedInteropTypes` for those types of projects and the `.target` only for .NET Standard/Core?

The project where I am trying to achieve this is: https://github.com/Roemer/UIAutomation-Interop
Any help would be greatly appreciated.

Thanks
Roman

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Support for OptProfV2 CI runs in Escrow mode" (#8671) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody: In https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/8578 , we disabled OptProfV2 related CI tasks to unblock the NuGet 5.3 release on VS. Now, we want to re-enable them to provide training data for 16.4 release, even when escrow mode is on course.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Using OData to query NuGet.org repository is being deprecated" (#37) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
We introduced `V3 APIs` in early 2016. We have made continuous investments to make it more reliable, performant and secure. Going forward, we plan to bring all new features and improvements only to the newer `V3 APIs`. As part of this strategy, we are deprecating the usage of `OData` queries. Subsequently, we plan to **disable the `OData` queries starting Feb 5th, 2020**.

**Call to Action: Transition to V3 APIs**

Here are some resources to help you with the migration:
* [NuGet Server `V3 APIs` reference](https://devblogs.microsoft.com/nuget/switching-from-wcf-odata-to-web-api/)
* [Guide to transition from NuGet `V2 API` to `V3 API`](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/nuget/guides/api/query-for-all-published-packages). 
* [Blog post: Switching from WCF OData to Web API](https://devblogs.microsoft.com/nuget/switching-from-wcf-odata-to-web-api/)

If you need further help in moving your use case to `V3 APIs`, do reach out to us at [support@nuget.org](mailto:support@nuget.org).
